>>15165451
I remember reading some paper from early 2003 (like just after columbia, it clearly wasn't edited for it) that compared the Orbital Space Plane programme with early 1970s Office of Management and Budget (OMB) scope statement for the shuttle, they didn't want NASA to spend too much on the shuttle so they proposed a smaller one, <14 tons payload. Anyway that paper compared the political, technical, economic situation, interagency relations and concluded that the OSP was not going to achieve anything without learning from the lessons of the shuttle and OMB's proposals.

But yeah, it wouldn't have been pretty, COTS would have no chance of happening, NGLT and OSP probably continues through the decade until 2009 when recession + obama getting elected cancels it.
By 2010 it's like IRL except no Dragon, no F9, no Antares, no SLS or Orion on the horizon, and the shuttle probably keeps flying until the late 2010s. The "good" side is that the gap in crewed american capabilities will probably be shorter.

I think space solar could be a big customer for starship.

You have to think like starlink, it's initial goal is not to compete with grid energy, but to provide energy off the grid.
You can get really out of the box with this as well: electric drones that can fly, sail or crawl indefinitely without having to carry heavy batteries or rely on intermittent solar power.
Powering laser thermal craft or dark side bases on the moon.
Providing power to other satellites in orbit.
Enabling very low orbit satellites etc.

>>15165957
Heat "losses" go towards warming up the surrounding bedrock and resulting in less and less heating required. Eventually the system can reach a thermal equilibrium where the basic activity where people move around is enough to keep the habitat at a comfortable temperature.
As for the melting and shifting of ice, there's no ice in solid bedrock, and even if a deposit of ice is found, that's what reinforcements are used for. You excavate a hollow to remove as much ice as you can, then backfill with dry tailings, then inject a binder to cause the whole mass to harden into a single big lump.

posts.com: Can we use the Banach–Tarski paradox to create an isomorphism between R and R^2 under their standard Euclidean metric, and if not how would you explain that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15166342
>an isomorphism between R and R^2 under their standard Euclidean metric
No, there is no such isomorphism (aka homeomorphism). Proof sketch: You can decompose R into [math](-\infty,0) \cup \{0\} \cup (0,\infty)[/math], but R^2 cannot be decomposed like this (two disjoint open sets and a singleton).

The reason Banach-Tarski doesn’t contradict this is that a homeomorphism is by definition pretty orderly (continuous) but the objects provided by Banach-Tarski are extremely disorderly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15166372

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No, we cannot use the Banach-Tarski paradox to create an isomorphism between R (the set of real numbers) and R^2 (the set of ordered pairs of real numbers). The Banach-Tarski paradox is a result in set theory that states that it is possible to decompose a solid ball into a finite number of disjoint pieces and then reassemble those pieces to form two balls, each of the same size as the original ball. However, this result is based on abstract set theory and does not hold for spaces with additional structure, such as the Euclidean space.

In Euclidean space, the concept of "length" or "distance" between points is well-defined and satisfies certain axioms, such as the triangle inequality. As a result, it is not possible to create an isomorphism between R and R^2 under their standard Euclidean metric using the Banach-Tarski paradox.

>>15166250
As >>15166515 says, medication aren't a panacea. They don't magically fix things.

All they can do is help give you a springboard, a solid ground to start from and build your life back up.

When it come to which med works, it differs from person to person. Different meds work differently well for different people.

My suggestion is keep a discussion open with your doctor as you test them out, weigh negatives vs positives and, critically, use that time to build good habits. Learn what sends you into depression and how to avoid it. Cognitive behavioral therapy also is scientifically proven to work as well as, or better than, medication.

Seeing a therapist can be greatly helpful in figuring yourself out, but it's not a necessity.

Personally I need social interaction once a week, a schedule, proper food and a modicum of excercise to feel good. If I notice my apartment is getting messy, I'm trying to stave off sleep and/or not wake up early and find myself not eating well, those are hard signs I'm slipping back and hence when I execute counter measures. I make sure to visit friends, go for a walk, eat out if I have to, as long as I est proper. I also write lists of what needs doing and its priority then focus on that. As I said, the specifics are different for everyone though.

And if there's one thing to take away from this it's hey, you're not alone and there is a way to get better and wrest control back from that black dog depression

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15164338
>Big Bang came from nothing
But it did not. What we call Big Bang is the sudden change in the initial singularity which was THE universe at the time. So there was a sudden change in its configuration for an unknown reason. We know (or think we know) what it was like for the first very tiny fraction of a second, but we don't know (and we can't even guess) what it was like prior to that. Which is to say that science (both our models and our best hypotheses) end at some point. In other words, we don't know what "made" the initial singularity or what was prior to that (if that even makes any sense, since time as we know it started with the Big Bang itself).
As for nothing: there's no such thing, according to science. Nothing is a human concept, just like sadness, urgency, etc... The initial singularity is not nothing. The vacuum is space, even without atoms and dust, is not nothing. There are virtual particles popping in and out of "existence" even in vacuum, and then there's other possible fundamental stuff like the quantum field and (possibly) strings and branes. So it is a mistake to believe that nothing exists outside of a conceptual description.
Alas, it is possible (not likely) that CCC is a thing. We cannot know/guess/model anything past a certain point going backwards in time and in the formation of the initial expansion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's not a stupid question, it's a rather subtle point. The basic reason why there is a difference is in how astronomers measure distance, which is with redshift.

If we take a very simple model and assume there is no acceleration or deceleration and the Hubble constant is fixed. If we see a galaxy at a redshift of z = 0.233, which is a recession velocity of 70,000 km/s. This is the velocity that comes from measuring the shift in the galaxies light with the expansion of the universe. If we believe the Hubble constant (H_0) is 70 km/s/Mpc then we infer a distance to this galaxy of 70000/70 = 1000 Mpc (megaparsecs). But what if the universe were expanding faster? Well, we still measured a redshift of z=0.233. So say, H=700 km/s/Mpc then the distance we estimate is only 100 Mpc. 10 times less. So we see that if the universe is expanding faster a given redshift implies a lower distance.

This also applies when thinking about acceleration, in this case we say the Hubble constant today is the same regardless. If the universe is decelerating then the Hubble parameter would be higher in the past. This means that a given redshift corresponds to a smaller distance than an accelerating cosmology.

In my previous distance calculation I used a local approximation, more generally we have to integrate the distance in the case of a variable Hubble parameter (H(z)).

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_measure

You can see if you look at the equations used to calculate distance vs redshift in different cosmologies. The integral of comoving distance is the most important, other distances are related to it (such as the luminosity distance relevant for e.g. supernovea). It is related to the integral of 1/E(z) or H0/H(z). So you see if H(z) is higher in the past then the comoving distance is less.

>My question is, we know how fast we are drifting apart, but why would a farther distance mean we are expansion is accelerating?
The acceleration is inferred from the distribution of galaxies observed at different red shifts. In cosmology, red shift is a proxy measurement for distance due to Hubble expansion. However, the observed distribution is not consistent with Hubble expansion because the data shows too many galaxies at higher redshift. The first way that people imagined this distribution could occur was if the spatial part of the universe was expanding increasing quickly as time goes by. However, exciting new data from the JWST shows that the properties of high-Z objects (high redshift) are more consistent with expansion in the time sector of spacetime rather than the space sector. (This was the main idea proposed in the paper which is now called SCP-001, btw.) In fact, I think the secret they aren't telling yet is that accelerating spatial expansion has been ruled out by the new data.

(It is possible that I have slightly oversimplified redshift as a proxy for distance. I am not sure exactly that I remember what data are sampled in the dark energy surveys but I think it's like I said.)

Just came here to disucss some perspectives

Four meta-analyses of trials of homeopathic remedies that used the double blind placebo trial design drew positive conclusions.

a) In 1996, Boissel et al. reported on 15 high-quality trials and concluded that “There is evidence that homeopathic medicine is more effective than placebo”. (Boissel et al., Rep Eur Comm, 1996).

b) Linde’s meta-analysis reported on the results of 89 trials which were considered to be of sufficient methodological quality (Linde et al., Lancet, 1997). After a thorough statistical analysis they concluded, “The results of our meta-analysis are not compatible with the hypothesis that the clinical effects of homeopathy are completely due to placebo”. This paper generated a heated debate in the scientific literature.

c) Linde and Melchart (1998) in their systematic review of classical homeopathy also performed a meta-analysis of the results. They concentrated on 32 trials of classical homeopathy and concluded, as stated previously, in favour of an effect of homeopathy.

d) Cucherat’s meta-analysis concluded that: “there is some evidence that homeopathic treatments are more effective than placebo; however, the strength of this evidence is low because of the low methodological quality of the trials” (Cucherat, Eur J Clin Pharmacol, 2000)

Of these five meta-analyses, three were included in the NHS Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) held by the highly respected Cochrane Library (Linde et al. 1997, Linde & Melchart 1998 and Cucherat 2000). All five meta-analyses concluded in favour of homeopathy. Generally reviews have highlighted the weakness of the evidence and hence the need for more high-quality trials – a common finding of reviews and meta-analyses in conventional medicine.

This has got me fucked up, bros.

All laws of nature can be described with differential equations. All differential equations contain initial values that inform what is measured at any point in time from those initial conditions. This means that when the universe was created, everything that would have ever happened was already determined from the beginning.

Therefore, there is no such thing as free will.

Learning this killed me. Even if science killed god, I thought at least we could take comfort in being the masters of our own destiny, but we're literally not. From the moment our brains start working the last thought we'll ever have is determined.

There is no respite in chaos theory or quantum mechanics, either. Chaos theory is just a description for hard-to-predict systems, but those systems are still determined by their initial conditions. Quantum mechanics is truly random, on the other hand, but they aren't influenced by anything else in nature. That's what makes it truly random.

>>15156453
Not with the current generation. The issue is memory usage grows quadratically with #tokens. That's why chatGPT output is limited. There are ways to stitch it together, but it's all, everything, memory limited. That's why no video. That's why images aren't past a certain size (again, possible by stitching things, not the same)

The problem in "stitching together" code is everything must interlock perfectly - variable, function calls, operations, etc. Not easy with present tech.

5, 10 years from now, likely they're going to make memory usage most likely grow linearly (or a little more) with #tokens with corresponding hardware memory increases ~TB+. Now the AI can produce a whole movie, a whole book, a whole codebase. THEN you'll see people saying "write a frontend/backend/scraper/SQL for an engine that does XXX" and it will be written. So yes, that will be very bad for coding, but it will be bad for everything, because it also will mean "read a book", "write a book", "make a full length movie" "write a medical note", 'write a legal argument', etc etc... other more exotic stuff.. "hack this software" "make an organism genome" "propose a treatment for this disease"... "make a better CPU"... "make a better AI, and have the better AI make a better one"

The thought then is, this is all trained on prior code, so we will need coders to create new "ideas" and styles to fuel the AI. That's not a given, recently a paper was written where an AI developed a matrix multiplication algorithm that beats like 60 years of competition of academicians in terms of #operations, so humans aren't need there.

At some point someone will have a large neural net cluster, they'll be an automated AI that rewrites itself periodically. Left unattended, and connected to the internet, that's when singularity type shit will go down, best to have a non-internet connected data store

But hey even if that's the case... will need lots of people to manage the AI, QA, sysadmin, etc.

Linear Algebra 1:
This unit will consider problems arising from science, engineering, and business-related fields. True but I don't have a slick proof.
>inb4 why is it true
Closed subsets of S^2 are compact, so we immediately have that they have a finite number of connected components. These connected components are also all at a positive distance from each other, so we can put them in very tiny balls within the sphere. Then, we choose two connected components and argue from the cohomology group of the twice-punctured sphere.

>>15164211
>Fermat’s last theorem would imply this, no?
I don't see how
>Could you remind me what it means for a curve to be projective?
There are some subleties (especially over a non-algebraically closed field [math]k[/math]), but the gist of it is that a projective variety over a field [math]k[/math] is the subset of [math]\mathbb{P}^n_k[/math] given by the vanishing of some homogeneous polynomials [math]f_1(x_0,\dots,x_n),\dots, f_m(x_0,\dots,x_n)[/math]. Remember that it makes sense for a homogeneous polynomial [math]f[/math] to say that [math]f[/math] vanishes at a point [math]P[/math] of [math]\mathbb{P}^n_k[/math]. Then, a projective curve is a curve which is projective.

Now in the case at hand the context was
>does a cubic count as an elliptic curve?
So presumably one is given a cubic polynomial in two variables, say [math]f(x,y)=3x^3+4y^3+5=0[/math], and considers its solutions in the affine plane [math]\mathbb{A}^2[/math].
What I meant to say is that we first need to "make this projective" by "adding points at infinity", by which I mean to perform the standard operation of taking [math]f(x,y)[/math], making it homogeneous ( [math]F(x,y,z)=3x^3+4y^3+5z^3[/math] ), and considering this as a projective curve in [math]\mathbb{P}^2[/math].
Note that whenever [math]z\neq 0[/math], we can normalise [math](x:y:z)=(x/z:y/z:1)[/math], and we are reduced to the "affine case". When [math]z=0[/math], we get the homogeneous equation [math]f(x,y,0)=3x^3+4y^3=0[/math], which consists of a finite number of points

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15166219
NTA you replied to but this looks fine so far.

The equivalence between (3) and (4) boils down to the fact that [math](\forall x(\phi_1\to\psi))\land\forall x(\phi_2\to\psi)[/math] and [math]\forall x((\phi_1\lor\phi_2)\to\psi)[/math] are equivalent.

If you expand your bounded universal quantifiers, remembering that [math]\forall x\in X\,\,\phi[/math] is short for [math]\forall x(x\in X\to\varphi)[/math], you will recognize that this is an instance of the aforementioned equivalence (you'll also need to appeal to the definition of [math]\cup[/math] once to get there).

As for actually proving the equivalence mentioned earlier, it's a combination of the fact that universal quantification distributes over conjunction, [math]\forall x(\alpha\land\beta)\equiv(\forall x\,\,\alpha)\land\forall x\,\,\beta[/math], and also that [math](\phi_1\lor\phi_2)\to\psi\equiv(\phi_1\to\psi)\land(\phi_2\to\psi)[/math], which basically states that disjunction is the least upper bound w.r.t. implication.

You just prove them (informally) the way you prove everyday mathematicial statements.

To prove that [math](\phi_1\lor\phi_2)\to\psi[/math] implies [math](\phi_1\to\psi)\land(\phi_2\to\psi)[/math], you suppose [math](\phi_1\lor\phi_2)\to\psi[/math] and prove each of the conjuncts in the conclusion separately.
For [math]\phi_1\to\psi[/math] you continue by assuming [math]\phi_1[/math] and trying to derive [math]\psi[/math].
However if [math]\phi_1[/math] holds, then so does [math]\phi_1\lor\phi_2[/math].
But we still have that [math](\phi_1\lor\phi_2)\to\psi[/math] and so [math]\psi[/math] follows by an application of modus ponens.

The converse, i.e. that [math](\phi_1\to\psi)\land(\phi_2\to\psi)[/math] implies [math](\phi_1\lor\phi_2)\to\psi[/math], follows similarly but requires the usage of some other rules of inference (proof by cases, since the proof will inevitably assume a disjunction, namely [math]\phi_1\lor\phi_2[/math]).

>>15149682
>choose x_0 in [0, 1], such that f(x_0) >= f(x) for all x in [0, 1] (exists because of the Extreme value theorem)
>choose x_1 [0, 1], such that f(x_1) < f(x_0)
>define [math]\epsilon[/math] := |f(x_0) - f(x_1)|/2
>f is continuous, therefore
[math]\exists\, \delta > 0\, \forall x \in [0, 1]: |x_{0} - x | \leq \delta \implies |f(x_{0}) - f(x)| \leq \epsilon[/math]
>this delta is the epsilon you're searching for
In case the function f is a constant polynomial, you'll have to find another solution

I absolutely hate probability, can someone help me with two assignment questions?

"At a school there are 40% girls and 60% boys. Three quarters of the girls and half of the boys have a tablet. We randomly select a student and look at the event:

J = "the student is a girl" and N = "the student has a tablet"

a) Determine the probabilities P(N | J) and P(N).
b) Determine the probability P(J | N)."


And lastly, I've done the first part of this but the second question fucks me.

"On a pin code lock, we can see that the numbers 1, 3 and 4 are heavily worn, so we assume that the pins required are made up of those three numbers"

B) If the code has four digits: how many different 4-digit codes are there, that only
using the digits 1, 3 and 4? (NOTE: make sure you actually use all three of these digits!)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15150222
b) is 1/2.
10% are girls with no tablet
30% are boys with no tablet
30% are girls with tablet
30% are boys with tablet
We sum up the latter two categories to make 60%.
So P(J | N) = 30%/60% = 1/2

B) is 36.
We know that one of the numbers is used twice, and the other two once each. So that can be any one of the three numbers.
We then find the number of possible combinations given two of one number, and one each of two other numbers. That's 4!/2! = 12.
So the answer is 12*3 = 36

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15152167
>What is the best way to debug latex?
Same way you debug any language, really:
>read the logfile (it has file extension *.log)
>delete and rebuild all intermediate files (including the index/bibliography/whatever else you happen to have)
>isolate to a minimum reproducible example (ideally with at most one instance of \usepackage)
>google the error message (or check TeX SE)
>read the package documentation and (as a last resort) source code

I meant simple in the colloquial sense, as in possible to write down using elementary functions by hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15154960
Given two real numbers a and b, represent them both in binary and look for the first place where they differ (i.e. where a has digit 0 and b has digit 1). Then truncate up to that digit (i.e. get the common initial prefix of the binary representations of a and b) and you have a (dyadic) rational in betwen them.

that anon in your thread gave that correct answer.
one ground is "input" and the other is "output". its just so you can provide ground to your pump.
as for the difference between live, ground, and neutral, live is the positive voltage, ground is zero volts, and neutral is the negative voltage. imagine if you stacked two AA batteries on top of each other. measuring the voltage from the middle node (where the two batteries meet) to the top would be 1.5v, and measuring from the bottom to the middle is also 1.5v, but measuring from the bottom to the top is 3v. thats basically whats happening when youre measuring 110v across live/neutral to ground, and 220v measuring from live to neutral. they're two sin waves that are 180 degrees out of phase (flipped over, basically), so you get double the voltage. three-phase power is also common, which would be a sin wave thats 120 degrees out of phase with live, which ends up with [math]110\sqrt{3}[/math] volts, which is like 170 or something.

>>15157792
> as for the difference between live, ground, and neutral, live is the positive voltage, ground is zero volts, and neutral is the negative voltage.
This is nonsense. Neutral and ground are at roughly the same potential (they're connected together at the main board). The difference is that neutral carries the return current, ground isn't supposed to carry any current. Any exposed metal (e.g. casing) is supposed to be connected to ground so that if any live part comes into contact with exposed metal, it trips a fuse or breaker (but if there's a RCD, that will trip first).

>>15157855
> you arent gonna trip any breaker or blow a fuse if you run current to ground.
Shorting neutral to ground won't blow a fuse (but will trip a RCD). Shorting live to ground will blow a fuse for the same reason shorting live to neutral will.

> OP said it himself (in the other thread):
> > Touching one of the leads to the input neutral and the other to ground or output also gave me 110V.
That's not neutral. In the US, a 240V appliance has two live ("hot") wires (which are 180° out of phase) and no neutral. Neutral is (nominally) at ground potential, although it might differ by a volt or so due to the neutral current and Ohm's law.

Saved others a click:

Say I wish to solve the inequality [math]|x-1| + |x+1| < 2[/math]. Now, we can make use of the alternative expression for absolute values: [math]|a| = \sqrt{a^2}[/math], and what follows is:

[eqn]|x-1| + |x+1| < 2\\
\sqrt{(x-1)^2} + \sqrt{(x+1)^2} < 2\\
(x-1)^2 + 2\sqrt{(x-1)^2}\sqrt{(x+1)^2} + (x+1)^2 < 4\\
(x-1)^2 + 2(x-1)(x+1) + (x+1)^2 < 4\\
[x^2-2x+1] + 2[x^2-1] + [x^2+2x+1] <4\\
4x^2 < 4[/eqn]

which reduces to:

[eqn](x-1)(x+1) < 0[/eqn]

which is true for [math]x \in (-1,1)[/math], but clearly it does not satisfy the original question, since the LH side of the inequality above is equal to 2 in this select part of the domain (and it can easily be shown that the statement is altogether false by taking cases).

My question is: where (and why) exactly does the algebra fail?

[math]x^2 + x[/math]

Basically, you want to do the following:
- [math]f'(x) = 0[/math] for [math]x \in (- \infty, b][/math], where [math]b < - a[/math]
- the first step, starting from [math]a[/math], has a large enough differential to shoot you to [math](- \infty, b][/math]

What I'd do in your case is look at [math]f(x) = e^{x^2} - c[/math] for [math]x \geq 0[/math] and [math]f(x) = -c[/math] for [math]x < 0[/math].

For each matrix M, I can direcrly observe the value [math]F(M) = \sum_{i} f(M_i)[/math] where M_i is the ith row of the matrix. I first thought it was impossible, but I thought about this example - if I have two matrices A and B that are identical (or at least very similar) except at one element [math]A_{ij} \neq B_{ij}[/math], then [math]F(A) - F(B) = f_j(A_{ij}) - f_j(B_{ij})[/math]. If [math]A_{ij}[/math] or [math]B_{ij}[/math] happen to be 0, then I know the value of [math]f_j[/math] at the nonzero one. Realistically, I doubt there are many instances of matrix pairs that are equal except for just one element, but there might be a good amount of pairs that are very similar. posts.com:
>>15160715
>But what happens when it never gets excreted?
Without function kidney, it won't get excreted, as will a myriad of other things in your bloodstream that'll end up killing you unless you get on dialysis to replace the kidney function. The kidneys aren't the only way the body elimitates medication, some are eliminated by the liver through the bile, some break down non-enzymatically, some you could technically breathe out

>I'm having a hard time wrapping my head around this. Why does it need to be reduced? Isn't the medication used in such a dose that gives it the desired effect (gets used up) and then you have to "replenish" it?
Some drugs also gets "used up", for instance by irreversibly binding to enzyms and inactivating them (like Aspirin), but other drugs only temporarily interact with whatever their target is. In general, as soon as you take medication, your body also starts metabolizing and excreting it. The dosage and dosing shedule reflects that, you want to administer it in a such a way that the concentration stays within the therapeutic range as long as necessary while avoiding side-effects/toxicity. If a patients kidney function is impaired, the elimination time for certain medications is longer and you'll reach the desired concentration with a lower dosage or get into the toxic range with a normal dosage, it's similiar for patients with imparied liver function.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15160932
>Or is my mistake, as you mentioned, thinking that all medication works by irreversibly binding to enzymes/receptors and in- or activating them? Is there medication that just flows around, occasionally doing its thing until it gets, for example, eliminated by the kidney?
Yes that's it, lots of medications work that way, they don't permanently bond, they interact in a statistical likelihood depending on their concentration, so it's in a balance like any chemical reaction. So you have a set amount of receptors that you want to target with a drug, you give a certain amount of the drug to built up a concentration of the drug in various compartments of the body that are in a chemical balance wih each other. Say one of these compartments is your intercellular space, another one is your blood and another compartment would be the molecule being bound to the receptors that you want to target. The concentration of the drug molecules in these compartments is in a constant balance. Your blood gets filtered by the kidneys, so the blood concentration of the molecules constantly decreases, which leads to molecules from the other compartments shifting into the blood and decreasing the amount of molecules that are bound to and interacting with the targeted receptor, so the effect of the drug starts wearing off. Even drugs that get used up work in that way, with the difference that the molecules that bind permanently to their target can't shift back into the other compartments, but the normal dosage you'll administer includes the anticipation that some of the drug will get filtered out before it can permanently bind to it's target. This is the general simplified gist of it

posts.com: if i select two integers at random between 1 and 1,000, what is the probability that their sum will be prime?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15165824
im looking for a novel proof, not just some brute force calculation

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15165288
There should be a range of positive integers [1,n],n∈N to solve this as a discrete math problem. That gives this a finite sample space [1,n], and the set of prime sums S={(i+j)|i,j∈N,i,j≤n,(i+j) is prime}.

The hard part is reducing the sample space [1,n] to the set of prime sums S. All prime numbers are odd except 2=(1+1) which means that even and odd sums are a way to exclude some (i+j)=k sums.

First, exclude all even numbers except 2=(1+1). The sum of two odd numbers is even and the sum of two even numbers is even. All these except (i=1,j=1) should be removed from the prime sums S.

((2s+1)+(2t+1))∉S,s,t∈N odd numbers

(2s+2t)∉S,s,t∈N even numbers

Next, only some odd and even sums belong to the prime sums S. Compute this set OE of odd and even sums and find the prime numbers within the set.

((2s+1)+2t)∈S,s,t∈N odd and even numbers (2s+(2t+1))∈S,s,t∈N even and odd numbers

They both reduce to the same form (2(s+t)+1).


Now use the number of elements |S| in the set S to find the probability P.

P(sum is prime)=|S|n

PE, PhD, or both. The only way you are worth a shit as a solo bolo engineer is with your stamp. You are still going to have to grind out 4 years at an A&E firm before you can even do that. You can always try your hand at being a freelance CAD monkey/Machine Designer but there are so many pajeets doing it for pennies that its not really a living.

There are some other niche specialties you can delve into like energy efficiency consultations, vibration analysis/predictive maintenance, but those are still going to require working for Mr. Toilberg for a while to get the XP needed to not be a complete amateur. After all that, you still gotta drum up business. Most likely your first customers will be mom n pop architect firms that need a mechanical designer for their plumbing and HVAC systems, simple stuff really, but it takes months if not years of persistence, pavement pounding, and unironically firm handshakes to get a client base.

t. licensed engineer w/ a freelance side hustle. if i wasn't making so much money at my day job i'd do it full time. fuckin' health insurance man.

Just a quick note; the thread is still early, and others may see this.

On one hand, >>15155363 is right. The tech industry was well past due for a shakeup, so if you were thinking of being a SWE, you might wish to reconsider given the current macroeconomic climate.
On the other, as many have pointed out before, CS is not circumscribed to the tech industry. Not at all.
>the possibility of a more advanced GPT being able to code at human level im not so sure

I'm going to go out on a limb here, and say that GPT will not, within this generation, replace people doing actual CS. Sure, IT and "tech", broadly, may see a shift in how people work, with a few humans, assisted by e.g. GitHub's CoPilot tool, doing the work we see done today by overstaffed companies.
But the heavy lifting will still be done by those well qualified enough to make profound contributions a statistical regurgitator like GPT cannot.

Please consider the following example: there is work being done right now to enable reliable (but still fallible) watermarking of texts produced by ChatGPT. I won't delve into details, because who better to do so than those working on it as we speak : https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=6823 (scroll down to "My Projects at OpenAI").

This is the kind of interesting, complex and worthwhile problem you can work on if you go all the way in CS: it is a combination of theoretical CS, pure and applied mathematics, cryptography, and some practical engineering to make it all work in reality.

If you're a math grad student, the work you'll have access to are far beyond what any version of GPT in the near future can even try doing.
Unless you want to become the millionth front end developer on the framework treadmill thinking building a CRUD + REST API is CS :)

>>15155973
>>15156012
Systems Engineering is not "a person who deals with systems", otherwise literally everybody in society ever is a systems engineer. A systems engineer is a special kind of engineer that engineers engineers, basically an engineering project manager, that you have to hire when projects get too complex. The problem is that in complex systems not everybody that works on them understands how every other part of the system works, that's obviously impractical, so knowledge in a project is necessarily extremely fragmented and you need somebody whose job it is to make sure the system as an integrated whole meets the million requirements that go into any complex engineering project. These people, the systems engineers, have to use special methods and software to deal with the complexity to make sure the project is on the right track.

It is the least "handwavy" engineering job imaginable. DoD contractors hire them by the hundreds because you can almost never have enough of them because they're empirically guaranteed to reduce project costs. The only reason it sounds like a meme field is because "systems" is obviously a vague word, and IT technicians will call themselves "systems engineers" because they think they ""engineer"" "IT systems". They're clueless philistine idiots. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_engineering

>>15156640
>>15156939
You'll adapt and do fine even if you're super introverted but you should know that systems engineering is a way more extroverted engineering role typically than any other because you're basically a project manager, it's literally your job to communicate with all sorts of different people working on every aspect of a project, even its stakeholders (people that have some kind of vested interest in the project).

>>15155488
Hey man, I would go for the degree in econometrics (+econ), if it allows you to do the master in fin math. If you have to take measure theory /stochastic processes /pdes before being allowed in I would do so during your undergrad (if not the programme is probably bad).
The job consists mainly of modelling stuff, where a very good grasp on econometrics is indispensable. I'm talking about the fundamentals, knowing stuff like when the output of a regression is explanatory and when it is questionable. Having a good head for inferential statistics is quite rare, too. Most of the computer science stuff can be self-taught next to your studies, if you want to. The advanced mathematics is actually useless beyond getting a better head for stats / numerical methods / basic models; if your model is very complex something has likely gone wrong, as opposed to what people in '''machine learning/data science''' will tell you.
There is the added prestige of doing a difficult master, but this is only important for getting an interview. Most firms will throw your resume out if you didn't study something technical (which econ is not) or do something interesting, but fin math should be ok.
Good luck.
t. have two degrees in econometrics and stochastics myself and been to a few quant firms for competitions &c, though I would never work there.

posts.com:
Calling all solid state physicists and chemists!

Despite much progress, the field of electronic structure is still plagued by proprietary licensed software. Access to the source code of these programs is the only way to understand both the theoretical background and advanced numerical techniques underlying these methods.

Some students are locked out of this due to the extortionate license fees demanded with profits usually not going to the contributes. Even those in well funded labs are disadvantaged by only having access to one or two of these proprietary codes and if they are focused on open source development and science it is likely they will not have any access at all.

If you are working with codes such as VASP, FHI-aims, Wien2k, Crystal, CASTEP or ONETEP or any other proprietary codes please post the source code or binaries here. Computational physics and chemistry codes from other fields are welcome too.

To start us off, here is an older copy of VASP from 2020 https://easyupload.io/la4ego (password: sci_code_share)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15161580

What's wrong with Fortran? It makes sense for numerics. It has built in array types with elementwise operations, good numerical libraries available and naive implementations tend to be faster than C++ and even C if you don't take care of aliasing issues.

People seem to dislike it just because it's old but it's had numerous updates which add OOP and coroutines.

Crucially it has its niche and still makes sense to start new projects in it unlike things like Cobol which are only still in use because people don't want to re implement things.

Realize that the liberal conception of freedom as simply "the ability to choose," isn't true freedom. That is, we can understand nature because it is rational (does not allow for contradiction) and we possess rationality.

This sort of choice based freedom is a contradiction. Once you make a choice, you have lost your freedom, as you can't make the choice again. It is a freedom that negates itself.

True freedom then evolves following ones true identity. Choosing ones friends and spouse puts obligations on one. It removes choice; so does choosing a vocation. And yet, by making decisions one makes these obligations necessary, and so control over necessity is the freedom we seek.

Absolute freedom then is the free will willing itself, the informed, self-conscious decision towards freedom. This type of freedom is not in conflict with limits or obligations, but emerges from it.

Basically, the liberal ideal of the modern world, embraced by both the modern left and right, is childish and self defeating.

>>15165015
There's a mucosal cavity that lies right behind your nose and leads down into your pharynx. That cavity tends to hold a lot of microorganisms that aren't necessarily prone to making a problem unless they make it down into the lungs, and the ciliary elevator does its best to move those guys back to be coughed up or swallowed. They swab so far back in there to access the top of that cavity where the nose connects and gather some of the dead epithelial tissue and mucus to see if there's enough of that microorganism to show positive for a test. Spit doesn't really cut it because there's not usually going to be enough there to show that you're positive.

Pathological science, as defined by Langmuir, is a psychological process in which a scientist, originally conforming to the scientific method, unconsciously veers from that method, and begins a pathological process of wishful data interpretation (see the observer-expectancy effect and cognitive bias). Some characteristics of pathological science are:

The maximum effect that is observed is produced by a causative agent of barely detectable intensity, and the magnitude of the effect is substantially independent of the intensity of the cause.
The effect is of a magnitude that remains close to the limit of detectability, or many measurements are necessary because of the very low statistical significance of the results.
There are claims of great accuracy.
Fantastic theories contrary to experience are suggested.
Criticisms are met by ad hoc excuses.

>>genetical engineering
No one knew about genetics until Mendel, and even then didn't know anything up DNA until Watson and Crick. Crispr and other genetic engineering techniques didn't even exist until much later. So no, no one had practiced genetic engineering.

At most there was selective breeding (not the same thing as genetic engineering as genes are not introduced into the organism nor removed purposely from an organism). Even then, it was just grass with big seed or trees with big fruit get planted while small seeds don't. Nice cattle get domesticated, mean cattle are just ignored and maybe hunted for sport (like Aurochs). That's how selective breeding works.

Whereas genetic engineering is extracting some gene sequences from a variety of bacteria and using some technology like Cripr to insert those genes into an organism to make it produce poison or to a plant resistant to the deadly slew of pesticides you just patented to sell with it for maximal profit while buying out regulatory agencies to protect you from litigation and negative attention that comes from your abominable business practices and disregard for human health.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15165321
No. Dusbowls happened because white settlers tilled prairie grasses with massive taproots (like what's pictured in the OP) and replaced them with shallow rooted wheat. The prairie grass's deep roots prevented soil erosion, but after they were gone it dried out and could be blown off by the wind even, hence why dustbowls happened. Most of the plains now has a shallow layer of topsoil even 100 years later on top of a thick clay layer, then bedrock.

In the great plains trees are a nuisance. They don't naturally grow because of the intense prairie fires the region is prone to. Chopping down trees unironically is good for the health of the region, since the native grasses have such massive rootsystems, if the tops are burned off they just regrow. Natural fires get hot enough to permanently kill off most trees, though that has changed since settlers arrived, we do controlled burns which don't get hot enough to kill trees, and thus woody encroachment is a problem.

>>15165366
The great plains are part of the midwest. In fact I would say that the "lower midwest" is synonymous with the great plains. The massive amount of desertification which happened in the US caused a heatwave, sure, but it was transient.

Turning the search for the "mystery PDF" into a code search or proof search task.
Let A be a submonoid of some free monoid and X an A-set.
Let X x| A = { (x,xa) : x <- X /\ a <- A }. Let B be a monoid and
d : X x| A -> B a map such that
>d(x,x) = 1
>d(x,xa)d(xa,xaa') = d(x,xaa')
for all x <- X and a <- A. Then d is a *differential action*.
Let A' <= A be a submonoid. The *differential subaction* for A' is the
action of A' on X plus d[|X x| A'], the restriction of d to X x| A'.
The category of differential actions is parameterized by (A,B)
In other words, a homomorphism in this category consists of
- submonoid of some free monoid A and monoid B
- A-sets X,Y and differential actions d,e
Then we should have d : X x| A -> B and e : Y x| A -> B. Now, to make this a homomorphism we need
- a map phi : X -> Y
the actual differential action homomorphism, that will hold the morphism data in this category
The homomorphism condition is phi(xa) = phi(x)a and e(phi(x),phi(xa)) = d(x,xa) for all x <- X and a <- A.
If phi is a bijection, then it is an isomorphism.
Let A' <= A be a submonoid and Y a subset of X. The *galois group* Aut[A'](X|Y) is the set of
A' differential action automorphisms phi : X -> X such that phi(x) = x for all x <- Y.

right regular differential action for a calc has the following meaning
We start with a submonoid of some free monoid A and a submonoid of a free monoid B.
A calc is a map e : A -> B such that
- e(1) = 1
- e(aa') <- e(a)B for all a,a' <- A.
The *shift* of the calc e by an element a <- A is the unique calc f = e^a with domain A and codomain B such that e(a)f(a') = e(aa') for all a,a' <- A.
The *right regular differential action* for the calc e consists of
- X, a copy of A, the right regular monoid action
- the differential map d(a,aa') = e^a(a').
We can then recover the original calc from the differential action as follows:
>e(a) = d(1,a)
as it is a fact that e^1 = e for all calcs e.

Let's solve the perimeter of the ellipse.

The ellipse, divided by major and semi-major axis is nothing but a constant curve that is repeated four times.

The curve is always tangent at the axes and the curve is always constant.

Therefore, if you simply solve for the length of the curve between the major and semi-major axis (in terms of pi) and multiply by four, you get the perimeter of the ellipse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15150396
It's Binary Homeworlds, in a nutshell: Upright pyramids are stars, pointing pyramids are starships of either side. Starships can take different actions depending on friendly and star colours at their location (build/move/change colour/attack). Stars are only connected (i.e. ships can move between them) when they are of different sizes. Thus you see the homeworlds consist of 2 sizes of stars, and from there you can only move to the remaining size. When 4 of a colour (including the star and both players' ships) are at a single system all pyramids of that colour are destroyed (and everything else too if the whole star is destroyed).
Ships are built from (and returned to) the shared bank which is the stash at the right. One must always take the smallest available size of a colour, but the larger sizes are obviously more powerful, so bank management is an important aspect of the game.
I found it via >>>/tg/bgg, and you can play it online on bga.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: This game I invented called empty go. Here are the rules. Two players alternate turns with black going first. Each turn consists of two phases. First the attack phase, then the maneuver phase. During the attack phase you can choose to attack any number of your opponents pieces. If you attack an enemy piece your opponents can choose to defend it. In order to defend it successfully, they must draw four straight lines, each line must connect the attacked piece to a different side of the board. This is done by pulling the twine taught above the board. In other words there must be a straight line connecting the piece to each side of the board for it to be defended. However, lines cannot pass through an enemy piece. During the maneuver phase place one piece on the board. You cannot play on top of or overlap another piece. Pieces can hang off the edge if the board as long as their center is on it. If you cannot place a piece, you lose. You can also lose by resigning.

I used to have a passion for mathematics, but my PhD experience was traumatizing. My advisor gave me poor advice that led to the failure of my research project, and my research papers were criticized and rejected by nearly everyone except my advisor who claimed to have a very positive opinion of his topic. One professor even told me to my face that I should have known better than to work on this project. The aftermath of my PhD made it difficult for me to find employment in mathematics and resulted in financial loss for my family. My mental health was severely impacted.

Recently, my advisor hinted that he may have been incorrect in his assessment of my project, and that I had potential as a student. However, this only fuels my bitterness. Some people tell me to get over it and move on, but I find it hard to move past my trauma and rekindle my love for math.

Is it justified to have an aversion towards a subject due to a traumatic experience?

>We need to start again value intellect
That's illegal in the USA. In the case Griggs v Duke Power, the US Supreme Court ruled that intelligence tests for employment are illegal because some races are more intelligent than others. Unable to test for general intelligence, companies turned to a proxy: the university degree.
Though not a perfect proxy for intelligence, at the time (1970s) it worked sufficiently well that most companies started adopting it as a job requirement for anything that required brain power. Since the "best jobs" now required a university degree, the government went about making sure that everyone, regardless of intelligence, could get one. This lead to credential inflation as companies increased their requirements for academic degrees while the government made getting such degrees easier and easier. In the middle of this all are universities, which are becoming insanely wealthy from this system, and workers, who have to go further and further into debt to get degrees that are proxies for a simple intelligence test.
Come up with a simple and low cost intelligence test proxy that can't be gamed and, just as importantly, won't be outlawed by the government for being a proxy, and you'll have solved the problem. This is unlikely however because the government is dead set on making sure that the dumbest people are able to access the "best jobs".

>what do you think of garden gnomes?
What an interesting heuristic. My most spontaneous answer is
>Gaudy, and not to my style if I hard a garden. I have conflicting views on the philosophy on garden gnomes: on one hand, they represent a human visual pollutant of a landscape that often (but not always) is supposed to put the delights of the natural world into the centerpiece. On the other hand, the inclusion of such may -- may -- indicate a certain quirkiness of the individual at hand, and definitely indicates a desire to "cozy up" a garden. The "may" is in reference that just as likely, they could just be included as thoughtless cliche because it's thought "belongs in certain gardens". Lastly, garden gnomes represent a connection to the traditional pagan folklore that underlies our culture here in the Indo-European sphere of the world.

I’m not convinced that there is self-awareness, or any other type of self-reference, for that matter. Self-reference generally results in paradox because it is simply incoherent. So when you say that we are conscious of our consciousness, or whatever, you should be really precise in what you mean. I can close my eyes, and notice the lack of visual stimuli that I normally see. Likewise I can close my ears, hold my nose, etc. I can also be conscious of the fact that time passes when I’m asleep, and yet I have no memories of any conscious stimuli when I ‘m asleep. This leads me to the realization that sometimes I am conscious, and sometimes not. Even to say “I am conscious” is not much different than saying “I am aware of the fact that I see a tree and hear birds when I could be seeing nothing and hearing nothing at all.” So I don’t get this emphasis on consciousness being conscious of itself, as if it is some sort of infinite mirror loop or something. You could use the semantic trick to say that your knowledge has knowledge of itself

posts.com:
Iq or any test only works when you're testing against a group (sample) of other people and comparing the results.
An individual score from some website is going to be inaccurate. Yes, you're being measured against their dataset, but there's no control over the circumstances of people doing the test.
Which is why examinations or tests are supposed to be done in person, with the same amount of study time.
At least then people aren't hacking the test or solving it as a group.
Everytime a test is taken, there'a always a range of ability which may be driven by many factors, one of which is your intelligence.

With enough people standardised testing shows a scale of results. if picking people from the top 15%, the chances are moderate that you are picking someone in the 85th percentile of intelligence

posts.com: Answer this: what, generally speaking, has a bigger influence on the general price index of a country: import fees, geographical position or salaries?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15164590
>geographical position
This is time-invariant, so its influence is constant and trying to disentangle it from all the other fixed effects is pretty much a waste of effort.
>import fees, salaries
These two may be confounded: rising national income usually leads to an increase in spending, of which some amount will go to imports. In other words, the influence of salaries can percolate into import fees.
Ignoring the caveat above, it is possible for import fees to be more influential than salaries, for example in a small entrepot economy where the volume of trade exceeds domestic consumption levels. Then the country's price index could conceivably be dominated by imported goods rather than domestic goods. However, this is a special case, and a general country's price index is more likely to be influenced by salaries (assuming typical wage-price spiral dynamics).
You should reach the same conclusion if you're a monetarist who believes that inflation is ultimately influenced by the money supply, since that is controlled by domestic rather than foreign authorities (aside from special cases like the eurozone economies), and in turn influences salaries rather than foreign import prices.

Utilizing Inferred Meterological Data Concerning Atmospheric Ceiling Boundary from Starlink to Improve Existing Atmospheric Models

Although the most advanced atmospheric computer models of today are both global and three-dimensional, weather forecasting leaves much to be desired. The single area of greatest potential improvement lies in rectifying the paucity of atmospheric sensors at high altitudes and over the ocean. Without an accurate, high-resolution, real-time snapshot of the atmosphere, we cannot hope to have accurate predictions of weather over periods of a month or more.

Until such a time as (perhaps photo-magnetically-propelled) sensors can be lofted at substantially high densities to generate a more complete picture of the atmosphere, there are other areas for improvement that are more easily achievable. Today's focus will be on solving the conundrum of predicting which weather system will be dominant when converging high and low pressure systems interact. This interaction is not only critical for predicting the trajectory of hurricanes, but also introduces the preponderance of uncertainty into ensemble models. If we can eliminate much of this uncertainty at these key "decision points" in the models, we can build a more accurate model.

Meteorologists understand that what the layman calls a high or low pressure system is actually an integrated column of atmosphere that broadly rotates in two opposing directions. Many do not understand that at mesospheric altitudes, the area immediately above a low pressure system is actually an area of relative (to the neighoring areas of the same altitude) high pressure that rotates in the opposite direction as the ground-level low pressure. Ground-level high pressure systems, conversely, feature a column of counter-rotating low-pressure at mesospheric altitudes.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
(My bad, screwed up the trip)

When low and high pressure systems are more or less evenly matched in terms of their relative strength and momentum, meteorologists look for other clues such as what surrounding weather systems are doing. This is at the essence of why global models are more accurate than continental models.

What these global models have in common is that they do not take into account a factor not often considered in fluid dynamics: The relative weight of the atmosphere in specific columns that extend to the atmospheric ceiling at between 108 and 115 miles of altitude. At points of uncertainty in a model, it is critical to be able to accurately decide how seemingly evenly-matched columns of atmosphere will interact.

I propose that by assigning an estimated weight to the atmosphere in a series of narrow columns (perhaps 5 miles in diameter each) and by estimating this weight by mapping the contours of the atmospheric envelope using Starlink data (this can easily be inferred from the rate at which ionic propulsion is called upon to counteract drag in this satellite constellation,) it can be accurately estimated which weather systems will be dominant in those cases where both seem equally potent. In nearly all cases, I believe it will be found that the dominant system will be the one featuring a greater weight of atmosphere above, typified by a bulge of troposphere that can impose drag on satellites.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
The reason for this being the case can be found not in traditional fluid dynamics, but in Newton's Laws concerning the transference of energy between systems. Anyone who has ever seen an automobile wreck knows that weight provides protection to a solid, ballistic object during a collision. Oftentimes, however, whichever object is moving faster, even when weights are identical, will better survive a collision not because of its weight, but because of its higher velocity. The product of mass and velocity determines energy and energy will always tend to flow from areas of higher concentration to those of lower concentration. For solid objects, this means that the object receiving net energy must experience the greatest G-forces. This abrupt change in direction that causes damage to an object can be traced to the injection of energy into that object, which in turn, can be traced to the asymmetry of energies.

When it comes to weather systems, while the momentum of pressure systems, the difference between the pressure levels of the two systems, and the activity of other bodies in neighboring areas do, indeed, remain the primary factors to consider if one wishes to accurately predict the future motion of these bodies, in the absence of complete knowledge of the state of the atmosphere, the relative height of the atmospheric envelope stands out as a heretofore overlooked variable we can easily measure that has the potential, in my judgment, to eliminate a great deal of uncertainty from the existing global forecast models.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes, it is possible to detect isolated ionizing radiation sources on Earth using multi-spectral sensors from space. One method is to use gamma ray detectors on satellites to detect gamma rays emitted by radioactive materials. These detectors can also be equipped with multi-spectral sensors to detect different types of gamma rays, allowing for identification of specific isotopes. Another method is to use hyperspectral imaging, which can detect the specific spectral signature of radioactive materials. This technique uses a wide range of wavelengths to identify and map the location of specific materials on the ground.

Additionally, there are also other remote sensing techniques, such as Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR), and LIDAR which could be used in combination with multi-spectral sensor fusion to detect ionizing radiation sources on earth.

>>15159649
Generally, the more sensitive a sensor, the smaller the area it covers. You might be able to use a satellite to detect it, but it would take forever to do so because it would have to scan very small areas at a time. Probably the quickest way would be to mount a wide boom to the back of a vehicle with sensors on it to sweep the road and nearby shoulder. The radioactive item gives off enough radiation that it should be detected easy enough that way. But there might be implementation issues such as parts of the road having obstructions that the boom would hit. Still, sending out several vehicles with sensors to cover the entire route and shoulder/ditch should get the job done.
The nightmare scenario is that another vehicle ran over the radioactive item and got it stuck in its tire or knocked up into its undercarriage. In that case, it could have been transported just about anywhere and eventually fall out just about anywhere.

I solved it but not elegantly. I started by rotating your triangle within the pentagon so that two of the vertices are on the midpoints of two sides of the pentagon respectively. Then there would only be one trapezoid formed within the pentagon, and the angles at its base would be equal.

Notice that the upper left vertice of your triangle is actually a pivot on the midpoint on that side of the pentagon. This means you can super impose the trapezoid in my picture on to yours (the blue line).

From there I assume there are better ways to do it. My idea ended up being turning the left and right side of the trapezoid into equations of lines and solving for the slope of the right one.
Then you can solve for the angle based on that slope, and work all the other angles out through subtraction.

>>15159464
I'm getting delta = 55.76124390703504.

delta = arccot[sin(66)*(cos(66)*(cos(54) + cos(18))+cos(54)*(cos(78)+cos(6)))/(cos(54)+cos(66)+cos(78)*cos(54)*sin(30)/sin(72))/(sin(72)*sin(36))-cot(36)]

Basically just >>15161103
I started with 6 equations (2 for each region of the pentagon).
One would use cosines to relate the lengths on the boundary to the length of the triangle edge.
One would use sines to equate the height of the altitude above the triangle edge.
You can use basic linear algebra to relate the length of the pentagon side, L, to the length of the triangle side, l.
You get l = c*L.
Then looking at the trapezoid in question, you can relate its diagonal, D, to L and l using sines.
D*sin(delta) = L*sin(72).
D*sin(alpha) = l*sin(66).
Dividing gives sin(alpha)/sin(delta) = (l/L)*sin(66)/sin(72) = c*sin(66)/sin(72).
Using alpha = delta + 36 and sine angle addition gives:
cos(36) + cot(delta)*sin(36) = c*sin(66)/sin(72).
Finally, cot(delta) = c*sin(66)/(sin(72)*sin(36)) - cot(36).

>texts me virtually every hour
This is the problem with text messaging and cell phones. It used to be the case that interpersonal interaction was expected to be either in person, over a letter, over email, or through a phone call when you are at home. Meanwhile, you at the library wouldn't have any interaction with these things unless you were using one of their computers or perhaps a payphone there. You had a strict boundary of space between yourself and other people when you needed to concentrate simply by going to a location where they can't find you and all you had to do is either go to that place and most normal people wouldn't going looking for you because they could leave a message on your answering machine and then understand that you'll call them back when you're able to if you even need to talk to them. Whereas now, the expectation of instant gratification from using text messaging on cell phones at any point of time has destroyed the sense of personal space/time here as now it's expected that you can inject yourself in some way into someone's personal space/time at the click of a button and expect a response.
>How can I balance working on my thesis and textbooks with maintaining a positive relationship with my girlfriend?
Try leaving off your phone when you need to concentrate. Try setting boundaries with respect to professional time and structuring your relationship around this. There is relationship time and professional time. Professional time is separate from relationship time. Explain clearly why exactly you need these boundaries and structure; you need time to concentrate on your work and you lose concentration if you're texted regularly. If your girlfriend is remotely reasonable, she will understand and adjust her behavior.
